question.scenario: You are an alien super-intelligence travelling across the universe to attend the *Intergalactic Conference on Lesser Intelligent Life*. On your way, you discover a previously unknown planet: Earth.
question.context: Using your advanced instruments, you quickly survey the planet's life and find two dominant life forms: (1) A bipedal, carbon-based organism that manipulates its environment extensively. (2) A widespread, silicon-based intelligence that also seems to shape the planet. Many other carbon-based organisms exist, but they appear strongly influenced by the activities of the carbon-based species.
question.task: As a galactic ecologist, design a study to investigate the drivers of the spatial distribution of these two dominant life forms.
requirements: What environmental and ecological factors might explain their distributions and uneasy coexistence?
How you would measure and analyse these drivers (e.g., gradients, biogeographic breaks, diversity metrics, environmental distance).
The likely impacts of these dominant life forms on less dominant species.
The major findings you would expect from your study.
question.theoretical_framework: Draw on ecological theory, biodiversity metrics, and human impact frameworks in your response.

criteria.name: Study Design
criteria.description: Assessment of methodological approach and ecological framework

scoring_bands.descriptor: Very vague, no clear ecological approach.

Mentions surveys, gradients, or biodiversity indices, but little detail, for example not mentioning sampling design using transects, quadrats, or other suitable sampling units, or the spatial scaling of the sampling units.

Clearly outlines how distributions would be studied, sampling design and spatial concerns, referencing ecological datasets, sampling, or macroecological frameworks (e.g., species–area, distance–decay).

criteria.name: Environmental & Ecological Drivers
criteria.description: Identification and explanation of distribution drivers

scoring_bands.descriptor: No mention of drivers or irrelevant ideas.
Identifies some plausible drivers (climate, resources, competition).
Explains multiple drivers with depth (gradients, niches, land use, dispersal, anthropogenic change).

criteria.name: Coexistence & Impacts on Other Species
criteria.description: Analysis of interspecific relationships and ecological impacts

scoring_bands.descriptor: No mention of coexistence or impacts.
Some discussion of competition or dominance.

Explains uneasy coexistence using ecological concepts (e.g., competitive exclusion, niche partitioning, disturbance) and discusses cascading impacts on less dominant carbon-based life (biodiversity loss, altered community structure).

criteria.name: Predicted Findings
criteria.description: Quality and grounding of expected research outcomes

scoring_bands.descriptor: No clear findings predicted.
Generic or superficial predictions.

Thoughtful, evidence-based predictions grounded in macroecological theory (e.g., human dominance as carbon-based driver, silicon life as analogy for machines/technology shaping environments, impacts on α-, β-, γ-diversity).

synthesis_bonus.description: If the answer integrates across multiple course themes with clear structure and originality (e.g., tying gradients, biodiversity indices, and anthropogenic impacts together), reward accordingly.

reasons: purely philosophical speculation without ecological grounding

grading_instructions.approach: Evaluate each criterion independently, then apply synthesis bonus and penalties

hidden_meaning.less_dominant_carbon_species: other biological organisms affected by human activity

questions.title: South African Green Party Policy Platform

question.scenario: It is the year 2034. After years of campaigning, the South African Green Party has become a strong political force, positioning itself as the official opposition to the ruling party.
question.task: As leader of the Green Party, write an opinion piece outlining the ecological solutions your party proposes for South Africa.
requirements: Show how ecological thinking can help address both environmental challenges (e.g., biodiversity loss, climate change, ecosystem degradation) and socio-economic issues (e.g., inequality, unemployment, food and water security) facing South Africans in the 2030s.
Integrate ecological theory, biodiversity concepts, and examples from South Africa and globally.
Avoid vague or generic statements such as 'plant trees', 'educate people', or 'develop policies'.
Ensure the socio-economic connection is covered, and show clear links to ecological theory such as IPBES concepts.

criteria.name: Ecological Solutions Proposed
criteria.description: Quality and specificity of ecological interventions

scoring_bands.descriptor: Vague or generic ('plant trees').
Specific ecological solutions, but limited explanation (renewables, restoration, sustainable farming).
Multiple, well-developed ecological solutions grounded in theory (ecosystem services, biodiversity resilience, conservation planning).

criteria.name: Link to Socio-Economic Problems
criteria.description: Integration of ecological solutions with social and economic challenges

scoring_bands.descriptor: No socio-economic connection.
Mentions jobs/food/water but weakly tied to ecology.
Strong integration: shows how ecological solutions (e.g., restoring catchments, renewable energy, agroecology) address unemployment, inequality, and security.

criteria.name: Use of Ecological Theory & Course Material
criteria.description: Application of theoretical frameworks and course concepts

scoring_bands.descriptor: No reference to ecological concepts.
Some references (gradients, diversity, ecosystem services).
Clear application of theory (e.g., species–area, α/β/γ-diversity, resilience theory).

criteria.name: Structure & Persuasiveness
criteria.description: Quality of argumentation and opinion piece format

scoring_bands.descriptor: Disorganised, weak argument.
Structured, some persuasion.
Clear, logical, compelling opinion piece with an ecological voice.

grading_instructions.approach: Evaluate integration of ecological science with political discourse and policy solutions
grading_instructions.contextual_focus: South African environmental and socio-economic challenges in 2030s scenario

question.task: Write a short reflective essay (no more than 0.5 of a page) on the most transformative insight you have gained during your studies at UWC.
question.context: This could be from BDC334 or from another course, fieldwork, lab work, or independent study.
requirements: What specific idea, skill, or experience changed how you think about science or the world?
Why did this insight matter to you personally or intellectually?
How did it challenge or overturn any preconceptions you once held?
How has it influenced the way you now approach questions as a developing scientist?
constraints: Avoid clichés (e.g., 'as a biologist, I have come to learn that all of nature is connected') or broad generalisations.

criteria.name: Specificity of Example
criteria.description: Concreteness and detail of the transformative experience or insight

scoring_bands.descriptor: Vague/general, could apply to anyone.
Some specificity but underdeveloped.
Clear, detailed example of a concept, method, or experience.

criteria.name: Depth of Reflection
criteria.description: Quality of introspective analysis and personal engagement

scoring_bands.descriptor: Surface-level statement of interest.
Some reflection on why it mattered.
Deep, personal or intellectual engagement with the idea.

criteria.name: Transformation & Preconceptions
criteria.description: Evidence of changed thinking and intellectual development

scoring_bands.descriptor: No mention of change in thinking.
Mentions a shift, but vague.
Clear evidence of how preconceptions were challenged and replaced.

criteria.name: Clarity & Authenticity
criteria.description: Quality of writing and genuine personal voice

scoring_bands.descriptor: Generic or cliché.
Honest, precise, and engaging writing.

grading_instructions.approach: Assess authenticity and depth of personal reflection rather than technical knowledge
warning_signs: Generic statements about nature being connected
Lack of concrete examples or experiences
positive_indicators: Connection between insight and future scientific approach

global_grading_instructions.assessment_philosophy: Evaluate understanding of ecological concepts through diverse formats: analytical study design, applied policy thinking, and reflective metacognition
cross_cutting_themes: Integration of ecological theory with real-world applications
Sophisticated use of biodiversity and ecosystem concepts

ai_grading_notes.context_sensitivity: Questions require different evaluation approaches - technical analysis, creative policy application, and personal authenticity
ai_grading_notes.avoid_keyword_matching: Look for conceptual understanding rather than mere terminology usage
ai_grading_notes.recognize_valid_diversity: Multiple valid approaches exist for each question type
